verses.text: For this reason, I, Paul, a prisoner for Christ Jesus on behalf of you Gentiles—
verses.comment: Paul presents himself as one suffering for the sake of bringing Gentiles into the mystery of Christ, prefiguring the universal outreach of God's plan.

verses.text: assuming you have heard of the stewardship of God’s grace that was given to me for you,
verses.comment: The stewardship (or 'dispensation') points to a particular ministry entrusted to Paul, highlighting the personal and ongoing transmission of divine grace.

verses.text: that by revelation the mystery was made known to me, as I have written briefly.
verses.comment: Paul refers to the 'mystery'—something hidden and now revealed—a core New Testament theme, with implications for church unity and apostolic revelation.

verses.text: By reading this, you can perceive my insight into the mystery of Christ,
verses.comment: Paul invites the church to apprehend his unique understanding, which strengthens the case for authoritative teaching through the apostles.

verses.text: which was not made known to the sons of men in other generations as it has now been revealed to his holy apostles and prophets by the Spirit:
verses.comment: Paul highlights the continuity yet development of revelation, laying stress on the apostles and prophets as divinely authorized interpreters.

verses.text: that the Gentiles are fellow heirs, members of the same body, and partakers of the promise in Christ Jesus through the gospel.
verses.comment: The mystery is that Gentiles become full members of God’s people through Christ, emphasizing unity and a visible community of faith.

verses.text: Of this gospel I was made a servant according to the gift of God's grace, which was given to me by the working of his power.
verses.comment: Paul's ministry is not self-appointed but divinely empowered, a pattern for how grace is mediated through chosen instruments.

verses.text: To me, though I am the very least of all the saints, this grace was given, to preach to the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ,
verses.comment: 'Unsearchable riches' highlights the inexhaustible depths of Christ—inviting ongoing meditation on his mystery and grace.

verses.text: and to bring to light for everyone what is the plan of the mystery hidden for ages in God, who created all things,
verses.comment: The divine plan is cosmic and ancient, rooted in the Creator’s intention from the beginning (see Gen. 1:1), integrating creation and redemption.

verses.text: so that through the church the manifold wisdom of God might now be made known to the rulers and authorities in the heavenly places.
verses.comment: This verse suggests God’s wisdom is revealed through a single visible body of believers, which becomes the instrument of God’s revelation to all realms.

verses.text: This was according to the eternal purpose that he accomplished in Christ Jesus our Lord,
verses.comment: God’s plan is not reactionary; it is eternal and accomplished in Christ, underscoring the unity of Old and New Testament purposes.

verses.text: in whom we have boldness and access with confidence through faith in him.
verses.comment: Access to God is through Christ’s mediation, affirming the ongoing necessity of trusting in Christ’s person and work.

verses.text: Therefore I ask you not to lose heart at my sufferings for you, which are your glory.
verses.comment: Paul’s sufferings are participatory in the sufferings of Christ (see Col. 1:24), implying the value and significance of suffering for believers.

verses.text: For this reason I bow my knees before the Father,
verses.comment: Paul’s posture of kneeling reflects deep reverence and humility in prayer, a model for Christian worship.

verses.text: from whom every family in heaven and on earth is named,
verses.comment: The text points to the Father as the source of all created order, emphasizing God’s providence and authority.

verses.text: that he may grant you, according to the riches of his glory, to be strengthened with power through his Spirit in your inner being,
verses.comment: Here Paul links spiritual strength to an internal transformation by the Holy Spirit, distinguishing between the external and inner realities of faith.

verses.text: so that Christ may dwell in your hearts through faith—that you, being rooted and grounded in love,
verses.comment: 'Grounded in love' indicates the necessity for charity and unity as a foundation for experiencing the indwelling presence of Christ.

verses.text: may have strength to comprehend with all the saints what is the width and length and height and depth,
verses.comment: A corporate understanding is encouraged—believers grasp the full mystery of Christ together, not as isolated individuals.

verses.text: and to know the love of Christ that surpasses knowledge, so that you may be filled with all the fullness of God.
verses.comment: To ‘be filled with all the fullness of God’ points to the ongoing deepening of communion with God, realized in and among the faithful.

verses.text: Now to him who is able to do far more abundantly than all that we ask or think, according to the power at work within us,
verses.comment: Paul’s doxology acknowledges God’s active work in believers, surpassing human expectation and petition.

verses.text: to him be glory in the church and in Christ Jesus throughout all generations, forever and ever. Amen.
verses.comment: The glory of God is manifested in and through the church for all generations—a call to see the visible, united community as central to God’s redemptive plan.
